awd_titl_txt: Population Growth and Human Behavioral Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Robert Kelly and his research team will investigate the relationships between environmental change and human population growth and decline on human behavior over a 12,000-year period in northwest Wyoming. With its ability to study long spans of time, archaeology is uniquely positioned to study, as in a laboratory, the impact of these two crucial variables on human societies. In doing so, this research helps determine if environmental change, including both long-term trends and short-term fluctuations, or human population density individually are sufficient to produce change in human behavior, or if the greatest change is produced by their  combined effect. Given that world population will reach 11 billion by AD 2100, and on-going environmental changes, planning for the future should make use of the best laboratory available, deep human and environmental history. Three graduate students will assist in this analysis and use the site’s data for their dissertations. Continuing a long tradition, Kelly will use the site’s analysis in public lectures to discuss the impact of environment and population on human behavior.

The project employs existing data, e.g., pollen cores from nearby lakes and a regional database of radiocarbon dates, to reconstruct environment and regional human population. The project’s main contribution is analysis of evidence of human behavioral change based on data recovered from an archaeological site, Alm Shelter, recently excavated by Kelly and his team in Wyoming’s Bighorn Mountains. Alm Shelter provides a 12,000-year record of human use, and, lying beneath an overhanging cliff, is dry and thus provides excellent preservation of organic materials. Often, the layers of earth that comprise a site have been disturbed, with artifacts moved about by burrowing animals or human activities such as digging pits. Thinking of an archaeological site as a book that one reads from the bottom up, such disturbances move paragraphs – artifacts and bones – from one chapter to another, making the book difficult to read. But that is not the case at Alm Shelter; this site’s layers are intact and accumulated at a slow rate that remained constant over time. This permits a unique analysis. Archaeologists use a statistical method known as an “age-depth model” to assign an age-range to artifacts based on their depth. Given this site’s careful excavation, a tight age-range can be assigned to literally every single artifact, bone, and other item recovered from the site. This allows a new analytical approach, one where the changing abundances of artifacts and other remains can be examined as distributions of age-ranges. These distributions can then be statistically analyzed to determine when different kinds of artifacts, such as projectile points, or different kinds of animal remains are changing in sync and how those changes relate to the known environmental and human population changes of the region’s past. Using artifacts, and discarded plant and animal remains as evidence of past human behavior, this analysis provides a way to examine how behavior changed in relation to environmental changes and human population density.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
NSF provided support for the analysis of archaeological materials excavated at Alm Shelter, Wyoming. Excavation occurred in 2005 and 2009 (test excavations), and from 2014-2018. The work as resulted in a Master's thesis (2021; Utah State University; site geology and OSL dating), a doctoral dissertation (Univ. of Wyoming 2022, site microbes and climate) and a preliminary study of the pollen profile  to track climate change(Univ. of Wyoming); two doctoral dissertations are underway with the stone tool assemblage (Univ. of Wyoming) and the animal bones (Univ of Georgia).

The site is located at the mouth of Paint Rock Canyon, on the west side of the Bighorn Mountains (see Alm Shelter-1). The canyon provides a transport corridor between the highest reaches of the mountains, to the east, and the Bighorn Basin, to the west. The stream, Paint Rock creek, provided water even during the worst of the early 2000s drought.

The site's importance lies in a remarkably intact stratrigraphy which has been densely dated through both radiocarbon and OSL methods (Alm Shelter-2 and -3), and consequently provides perhaps the best chronological record in the northwestern Plains region. The site's first use is about 12,000 years ago; there is no evidence of use in the early PaleoIndigenous period (i.e., there are no Clovis or Folsom components) even though the sediments cover these time periods. The heaviest use was in the Middle Archaic, but with use in the Early Archaic and Late PaleoIndigenous periods as well. The site saw far less use during the Late Archaic and almost no use in the Late Precontact period; this reflects a general decline in the precontact population of the high plains.

Linked to regional population estimates (based on a large radiocarbon database, created through another NSF-funded project, we can examine how population and environmental change (Alm Shelter-4) affected changes in how human societies organized their lives over the past 12,000 years in the region.

The intact stratigraphy allows us to date the various time periods of northwestern Plains archaeology, as defined by changing projectile point styles, with greater precision than previously, using Bayesian analysis (Alm Shelter-5 and -6).

Through time, the site was used primarily as a logistical hunting camp; the primary habitation site was located elsewhere (possibly at the Medicine Lodge Creek site, located about 5 km away; excavated in the 1970s with NSF support). However, the intact, well-dated stratigraphy allows us to see "pulses" in how frequently the site was used through time as tracked by changing densities of debitage (waste flakes from the manufacture and resharpening of stone tools; Alm Shelter-5). Analysis of these data will appear in a doctoral dissertation scheduled for completion at the end of 2023.


Last Modified: 06/01/2023
Modified by: Robert L Kelly

Images (1 of )
  • Alm Shelter is located beneath a large limestone cliff, 100 m from Paint Rock Creek, at the mouth of Paint Rock Canyon, in NW Wyoming. Facing east, the site receives morning sun and afternoon shade, while the canyon provides a major route connecting the Bighorn Basin to the Bighorn Mts
    Robert L. Kelly
    Robert L Kelly
    Alm Shelter-1
  • Upper left: drone photo of completed excavation, profile locations labeled in white; location of pollen sampling profile labeled in black. Pollen profile shown at right. Lower left: completed excavation, facing north.
    Robert L. Kelly
    Copyrighted
    Robert L Kelly
    Alm Shelter-2
  • Composite stratigraphic profile of Alm Shelter, with locations of sediment samples and samples for optically stimulated luminescence dating (OSL). The basal sediments exposed, at lower right, at more than 18,000 years old and consist of stream cobbles from a time when the creek ran through the site.
    Kayla Kennedy
    Copyrighted
    Robert L Kelly
    Alm Shelter-3
  • Alm Shelter pollen profile. Note there are two gaps in the record where pollen was not preserved. The cause of these gaps is still under investigation.
    Thomas Minckley
    Copyrighted
    Robert L Kelly
    Alm Shelter-4
  • Alm Shelter is densely dated by both radiocarbon dates. Right: Bayesian model of chronological periods. Left: the distribution of waste flakes, from ~12,000 years ago (far right on X axis) to present (far left). The changing densities point to changing intensities of site use.
    Alexander Craib
    Copyrighted
    Robert L Kelly
    Alm Shelter-5
  • Projectile point chronology of Alm Shelter. Earliest point styles at far right on X axis; the latest time periods (Late Archaic and Late Precontact) are not well represented as the site saw little use then. Primary use is in Middle Archaic.
    Alexander Craib
    Copyrighted
    Robert L Kelly
    Alm Shelter-6
por.por_txt_cntn:
NSF provided support for the analysis of archaeological materials excavated at Alm Shelter, Wyoming. Excavation occurred in 2005 and 2009 (test excavations), and from 2014-2018. The work as resulted in a Master's thesis (2021; Utah State University; site geology and OSL dating), a doctoral dissertation (Univ. of Wyoming 2022, site microbes and climate) and a preliminary study of the pollen profile  to track climate change(Univ. of Wyoming); two doctoral dissertations are underway with the stone tool assemblage (Univ. of Wyoming) and the animal bones (Univ of Georgia).

The site is located at the mouth of Paint Rock Canyon, on the west side of the Bighorn Mountains (see Alm Shelter-1). The canyon provides a transport corridor between the highest reaches of the mountains, to the east, and the Bighorn Basin, to the west. The stream, Paint Rock creek, provided water even during the worst of the early 2000s drought.

The site's importance lies in a remarkably intact stratrigraphy which has been densely dated through both radiocarbon and OSL methods (Alm Shelter-2 and -3), and consequently provides perhaps the best chronological record in the northwestern Plains region. The site's first use is about 12,000 years ago; there is no evidence of use in the early PaleoIndigenous period (i.e., there are no Clovis or Folsom components) even though the sediments cover these time periods. The heaviest use was in the Middle Archaic, but with use in the Early Archaic and Late PaleoIndigenous periods as well. The site saw far less use during the Late Archaic and almost no use in the Late Precontact period; this reflects a general decline in the precontact population of the high plains.

Linked to regional population estimates (based on a large radiocarbon   database, created through another NSF-funded project, we can examine how   population and environmental change (Alm Shelter-4) affected  changes  in how human societies organized their lives over the past  12,000 years  in the region.

The intact stratigraphy allows us to date the various time periods of northwestern Plains archaeology, as defined by changing projectile point styles, with greater precision than previously, using Bayesian analysis (Alm Shelter-5 and -6).

Through time, the site was used primarily as a logistical hunting camp; the primary habitation site was located elsewhere (possibly at the Medicine Lodge Creek site, located about 5 km away; excavated in the 1970s with NSF support). However, the intact, well-dated stratigraphy allows us to see "pulses" in how frequently the site was used through time as tracked by changing densities of debitage (waste flakes from the manufacture and resharpening of stone tools; Alm Shelter-5). Analysis of these data will appear in a doctoral dissertation scheduled for completion at the end of 2023.
